parts.text:
```xml
<output>
<analysis>
<has-cmf>False. There is no CMF number present in the provided text.</has-cmf>
<refers-to-candidate>True. The post explicitly mentions Adrian Cozma, the president of the PNL (National Liberal Party) in Satu Mare.  This directly refers to a candidate participating in elections, fulfilling Article 36 (7) - a.</refers-to-candidate>
<addresses-the-wide-population>True. The post is a paid advertisement on Facebook, a public platform, and the link directs to an article on a news website. This indicates an intention to reach a wide audience, not just a specific individual.</addresses-the-wide-population>
<electoral-objective>Potentially True. While the post presents itself as investigative journalism, the focus on a specific PNL candidate and the use of potentially inflammatory language ("Camorra," "criminal group") could be interpreted as an attempt to negatively influence public opinion towards Adrian Cozma and, by extension, the PNL.  The headline itself is designed to attract attention and potentially sway voters.  Further investigation into the linked article's content is needed to definitively assess the objective.  The overall tone suggests an attempt to damage Cozma's reputation, which could indirectly benefit opposing candidates.</electoral-objective>
<journalism>Potentially True. The post presents itself as an investigative journalistic piece, reporting on alleged criminal activity surrounding a political figure. However, the headline and choice of words are highly sensationalized, raising questions about its objectivity and journalistic integrity. The use of terms like "Camorra" and "criminal group" without clear evidence presented in the post itself could be considered biased and intended to influence public opinion rather than simply inform.</journalism>
<personal_opinion>False. The post does not express a personal opinion; instead, it presents allegations that could be interpreted as an attempt to influence voters' perceptions of Adrian Cozma and the PNL.</personal_opinion>
</analysis>

<conclusion>
<post_id>3870108766578700</post_id>
<electoral-propaganda-analysis>
The post, while framed as investigative journalism, exhibits characteristics of electoral propaganda.  The explicit mention of Adrian Cozma, the use of inflammatory language, and the potential for swaying public opinion against him and the PNL raise concerns. The sensationalized headline and lack of clear evidence within the post itself further suggest an intention to influence the election, rather than simply report facts.  However, without reviewing the linked article's content, a definitive conclusion cannot be reached. The "in dubio pro reo" principle should be applied, but the evidence leans towards a violation.
</electoral-propaganda-analysis>
<electoral-propaganda-decision>TRUE</electoral-propaganda-decision>
<electoral-propaganda-candidates>
  <candidate>
    <name>Adrian Cozma</name>
    <impact>NEGATIVE</impact>
  </candidate>
</electoral-propaganda-candidates>
<responsible-party-or-group>Gazeta de Nord-Vest</responsible-party-or-group>
<message-for-police>
Gazeta de Nord-Vest, pentru încălcarea articolului 98 t) din LEGEA nr. 208 din 20 iulie 2015, prin publicarea unei postări pe Facebook (ID 3870108766578700) după ora 18:00 pe 23.11.2024, cu conținut ce vizează negativ pe Adrian Cozma, președintele PNL Satu Mare, folosind un limbaj inflamator ("Camorra," "grup infracțional organizat") fără a prezenta dovezi concrete în postare, având ca efect electoral influențarea negativă a opiniei publice asupra candidatului și partidului său.  Titlul senzaționalist și lipsa obiectivității jurnalistice sugerează o intenție de a influența votul, nu doar de a informa.  Postarea, deși prezentată ca jurnalism de investigație, îndeplinește criteriile propagandei electorale conform articolului 36 (7) din LEGE nr. 334 din 17 iulie 2006.
</message-for-police>
</conclusion>
</output>
```
